14.91.text: Good afternoon, my name is Michelle Rhee,

17.07.text: I am the former chancellor of the Washington DC schools

20.53.text: I'm also currently the CEO of an organization called Students First.

25.26.text: And the whole idea behind Students First is a simple one,

30.04.text: if you look over the last twenty to thirty years in this country,

34.24.text: at the decisions that we have been making about education,

37.66.text: they have largely been driven by special interest groups.

45.65.text: You've all these organizations that have tremendous resources

50.14.text: and therefore tremendous influence on how decisions get made.

54.25.text: So, that's the way the world works.

56.10.text: The fact those organizations exist is not actually the problem.

60.44.text: The problem that we face is that there is no organized national interest group

66.12.text: with the same heft that, say, the teacher's union

68.34.text: that's advocating on behalf of children in education.

72.34.text: So, when children are left out of the equation

74.99.text: and no one is defending what is good and right for them

77.94.text: and you have all these other special interests

79.53.text: what you end up with is a landscape that is very skewed towards the adults

84.59.text: and very skewed away from children.

87.17.text: So, that's exactly what Students First aims to try to do,

92.27.text: and make sure that we have millions of members across the country

95.36.text: that are advocating for what children deserve.

101.84.text: because I was both the superintendent of a school district

104.00.text: and now I run this organization, people always say,

106.36.text: "What's wrong with education in America today?"

112.11.text: And often times people say, you know,

114.09.text: "Give us what the biggest issue in education is."

117.55.text: And I always refuse to answer that question.

120.52.text: I refuse to answer it because actually what is wrong with our system is pretty complicated

125.37.text: and when you try to distill it down to just one thing

128.35.text: then it sort of implies that if you solve that one thing

131.41.text: you're gonna fix all of the problems,

133.20.text: when in fact that is actually not true.

135.91.text: But people don't like taking no for an answer,

138.56.text: and so usually -- It is the press, the media, they're very persistent

141.71.text: and they go to me on, it's like, "Come on, tell us what it is!

145.42.text: It's the teacher's union, isn't it?

147.29.text: Or the parents, or we don't have enough money?

150.26.text: Come on, tell us what it is."

152.36.text: And you've actually probably heard a lot of this too,

155.33.text: you go to your cocktail parties

157.67.text: you and your friends sort of bemoaned the state of public education in our country,

162.40.text: and then inevitably it sort of devolves down into

164.37.text: what we need to do is invest more in our schools.

169.54.text: The question is: is that really right?

172.43.text: So, I'm gonna show you some data,

174.69.text: the first slide, when Americans are asked how much money

179.93.text: they think we are spending on public education in America today.

186.18.text: They think that we spend about four thousand dollar a year per kid.

191.69.text: The reality is that we spend several times that,

196.17.text: actually about ten thousand dollar a year.

201.19.text: and that is not the only disconnect

203.34.text: because when those same people are asked

206.23.text: they will very confidently tell you

208.44.text: that they believe if we spent more money on education

214.59.text: So take a look at this:

216.14.text: the red line shows the expenditure growth on education

220.89.text: over the last few decades in this country

223.34.text: and the blue line shows our academic achievement levels,

227.56.text: of our children in both reading and math

231.91.text: we have grown several times what we are spending

235.04.text: and yet our children's academic progress

239.91.text: This creates an incredibly difficult dynamic

246.26.text: where people are still trying to figure out what to cut in the budgets, etc.

250.23.text: Because if, for example, in the last few decades

257.03.text: and the achievement levels had also tripled,

260.86.text: then you would be able to say, "Ok, if you cut our budget by ten percent

263.78.text: this is the loss that you are gonna see."

266.51.text: But we actually can't show that at all,

268.06.text: in fact, in the last couple of years

269.93.text: there've been several states that have cut their education budgets

273.83.text: and seen their academic achievement levels rise

276.86.text: so we're in this really tough quandary right now

279.65.text: about -- you know, what the relationship is

287.38.text: So why is there this disconnect?

290.84.text: Where is all of this money going?

292.49.text: If we have grown the amount of money that we are spending so much

296.20.text: and we haven't seen the results, what's happening?

298.81.text: So I'm gonna tell you a very quick story from when I was the chancellor in Washington DC.

302.75.text: In 2007 I took over the Washington DC public schools,

307.36.text: at the time they were largely known as the most dysfunctional

312.47.text: and lowest performing school district in the entire nation.

316.83.text: Just to give a sliver of data to elucidate that for you:

322.65.text: of all of the 8th graders who were attending school in DC

327.76.text: in 2007 only 8% of them were on grade level in mathematics

333.59.text: 8 % -- which means that 92% of our kids

338.13.text: did not have the skills and knowledge necessary

340.55.text: to be productive members of society.

343.28.text: So, it was no surprise that the young upstart mayor

348.66.text: who had just been elected, his name was Adrian Fenty,

351.73.text: decided that as his major priority

355.16.text: he was gonna take on fixing the schools.

358.33.text: Because his theory was: you cannot have a great city

361.86.text: without a great public school system.

364.10.text: So, he decided to introduce legislation

366.55.text: that would allow him to take over

371.05.text: And he got the legislation past

372.48.text: and in June of 2007, as his first act of having control of the schools,

377.98.text: he nominated me as the city's first school's chancellor.

382.15.text: Now, I was a 37 year old Korean girl from Toledo, Ohio,

387.64.text: who had never run a school much less a school district.

391.77.text: So people were looking at him and saying,

395.82.text: Why would he think that she is a person

400.26.text: who can fix the most dysfunctional school district in the country?"

403.34.text: And so for days the thought that was teeming through everybody's mind was,

409.38.text: What on God's green Earth is Adrian Fenty thinking?

413.73.text: And that was pretty much what I was thinking

416.20.text: as I was sitting in my office

417.95.text: the first few days of my tenure,

420.40.text: thinking, where do you start when you have to fix

423.33.text: something where every single thing is broken essentially?

427.27.text: So, I was lucky enough to have lots of people who wanted to come in and help

431.59.text: and a number of these people had actually seen

434.18.text: what had been going on in the school district for several decades

437.72.text: and they had lot of thoughts about what needed to change.

440.33.text: Over and over again in my conversations with them

444.68.text: what they said to me was, "You have to find out, Michelle,

448.18.text: where all of the money is going."

450.73.text: Because we were spending almost more money in Washington DC,

455.30.text: per child, than any other urban jurisdiction in the country

459.09.text: yet our results were absolutely abysmal.

461.49.text: So, when you went into the schools

464.98.text: you saw teachers who had to buy supplies with their own money,

468.33.text: it did not feel like one of the richest school districts in the nation.

471.73.text: So it made sense to us that we would try to figure out where the money was being spent.

475.59.text: So, I sent my team out,

476.97.text: I said, you know, go look at every spreadsheet,

480.87.text: tell me where we're spending the money.

482.82.text: So, a couple of weeks later my special assistant comes back to me

485.20.text: and he says: "Ok, I did exactly what you said,

487.41.text: I looked at all of the largest budget items

489.88.text: and tried to figure out where they are going."

492.45.text: He said, "I have found two very interesting things."

497.04.text: Now, in education speak, interesting is code for whack --(Laughter)

503.28.text: So, the first thing that he says is,

505.78.text: "Number one: we are spending about ninety million dollars a year

510.30.text: transporting a few thousand special education kids through the system."

516.11.text: So, I do the quick back of the envelope math,

519.82.text: and it turns out that it's about 18,000 dollars

522.95.text: per year per kid on transportation.

526.60.text: So, I said, I don't know anything about running bus routes,

531.07.text: but I'm pretty sure I can do it for less than 18,000 dollars a year.

533.87.text: For 18,000 dollars a year you could buy the kid a Saturn the first year,

539.44.text: and a personal chauffeur for the Saturn every year after that.

544.10.text: So, I am confident that we can do it more effectively.

547.87.text: and the good news is that we're gonna be able to take the savings

550.52.text: and push it down into the classroom

552.20.text: where it's gonna have more of an impact on kids.

554.45.text: And he said, "Actually, not so fast."

556.33.text: See, the problem is that the district had done such a poor job

559.47.text: of transporting the special needs kids to their schools in the past

562.99.text: that now we're under a court order, a consent decree

567.26.text: and there's this court appointed special master,

569.82.text: and he has the responsibility for transporting the kids to school every day,

574.47.text: he's allowed to spend as much money as he wants,

577.73.text: and all we can do at the end of the year is pay the bill.

580.72.text: We have absolutely no ability to control cost.

584.44.text: And I said, that is the craziest thing I have ever heard!

588.02.text: And he said that's because you haven't heard titbit number two -- (Laughter)

592.69.text: He said i'm trying to figure out where are all these children going.

596.80.text: Washington DC is only a few square miles wide and long,

601.03.text: you could be doing laps around the city all day

603.62.text: and you still shouldn't be able to burn off 18,000 dollars worth of fuel,

607.12.text: so where is all the money going?

609.19.text: It turns out that we were not just doing a bad job

613.99.text: of transporting these special education kids,

616.39.text: we were doing a very bad job of educating them as well.

619.62.text: And this sort of culture became

622.19.text: that parents would sue the school district

625.48.text: because their kids weren't getting the services and resources that they needed.

628.78.text: We would inevitably lose that lawsuit,

630.93.text: because we were, in fact, doing a pretty sucky job

634.21.text: and then, the court would prescribe a remedy

638.38.text: and most often that remedy was that they would send them to a private school

642.75.text: and we would be required to pay the tuition to that private school.

647.40.text: And it was not just that, but every kid had a different remedy.

650.31.text: So, you had a situation where you might have a housing complex,

653.80.text: that had ten special needs kids living in it,

656.91.text: and each of these ten kids would all be assigned to a different school

661.34.text: in these far-flung places, in Virginia and in Maryland.

664.56.text: So you'd have ten different buses roll up in the morning

669.58.text: and ten different bus matrons who were making sure that the kids are ok on the bus,

672.83.text: all going in different directions to these far-flung places.

676.98.text: That was one of the reasons

679.84.text: that we were spending all of this money and not seeing any results.

683.78.text: Now, this is actually not just unique to Washington DC.

688.71.text: If you look at this next slide you will see

690.53.text: that since the 1970s we have had more than 26 states

696.15.text: have court mandated, sort of education finance cases,

699.78.text: that have resulted in really, really dramatic increases to funding,

706.10.text: And the whole goal of that was to try

708.18.text: to equalize things and make the education achievement levels

713.24.text: of minority kids more... equal to where it was for other children.

722.57.text: If you look at the minority achievement level in these 26 states,

727.34.text: in fact, a review of three states in particular

730.92.text: shows that the achievement levels of the minority kids in these three states

735.70.text: where they had these increases actually didn't even keep up with the national averages.

740.95.text: This is not just about the courts,

744.08.text: it is about lots of different special interest groups.

746.39.text: You have the state governments, you have the federal government,

748.90.text: you have school board, everybody wants to put in set-asides.

754.85.text: So, they say, we want some of this money to go to curriculum development,

759.01.text: we want some of the money to go to this community program,

762.33.text: we want some of the money to go to textbook adoptions,

764.72.text: and they mandate these set-asides and what it results in

768.67.text: is that of the 10,000 dollars that we are spending per child,

772.35.text: actually only about half of it is going into the classroom

775.48.text: where we think it's gonna have the most impact,

777.45.text: the rest of it is going to these other things.

779.73.text: So, this slide actually jives more with people's perceptions

784.00.text: of how much money is being spent,

785.83.text: because that's what they see in the classroom.

788.43.text: So, let's get to what needs to happen about it.

792.12.text: We need to stop spending money on things that do not work

796.78.text: and start putting our money towards the things that do.

801.27.text: More specifically what that means in a school district

804.53.text: is that we should set really specific goals

807.29.text: for what we expect a classroom or a school to achieve,

811.45.text: we have to give people the freedom

814.58.text: and the autonomy to make the decisions

816.20.text: about where those dollars are gonna be best spent to get to that goal.

820.50.text: Then we have to measure whether or not they met the goal or not,

824.81.text: and then we have to have some accountabilty,

826.55.text: so, if you did meet the goal or exceeded the goal

828.77.text: then we're gonna look at what you did

830.12.text: and we're gonna share those best practices with others.

832.24.text: And if you did not meet the goal

833.93.text: then we're not gonna let you spend the money in the same way.

837.14.text: But that is not the way that we run things.

840.18.text: So, in order to change the system

842.71.text: it's not just gonna require a change with the courts and the federal government.

847.56.text: It actually also requires a cultural change.

851.40.text: And let me tell you why. As a parent, and I have two kids,

854.87.text: I had this perception of what school should look like for my two daughters.

859.35.text: So when my daughter went to kindergarten,

861.73.text: I thought, I want a grandmotherly woman

864.94.text: who has had a long teaching career,

867.67.text: who will take my daughter on her lap, and read her a book

870.91.text: and if she's only in the classroom with 15 or 16 other kids,

874.41.text: that's gonna be better for my child.

876.46.text: What I don't want is for her to be sitting in front of

879.51.text: you know, computers, in front of a computer screen

882.31.text: because that seems cold and rigid and that sort of thing, right?

885.52.text: So this is what we believe

886.97.text: we hold as our -- sort of beliefs.

890.00.text: But the reality actually is that the research shows

894.10.text: that class size largely doesn't matter.

897.08.text: If you have a smaller class size versus a larger class size,

899.60.text: it doesn't have that much impact on a student's achievement levels,

901.93.text: and the latest data that's coming out from some of these new programs

906.31.text: that utilize technology pretty heavy in the classroom

909.11.text: shows very good results for kids

911.23.text: because you can differentiate for the individual needs of every child.

916.06.text: So, at the end of the day what we have to do

919.93.text: is ensure that we are not continuing

923.05.text: to spend more money and not fix the system

926.88.text: and expect that we're gonna get a different result.

929.91.text: What we need to do is something very very different

933.16.text: we have to reinvigorate the system

935.48.text: by investing in what works and by innovating.

939.26.text: So, the bottom line is that the next time you go to a cocktail party

943.88.text: where you hear your friend Ted say

947.00.text: that we've gotta spend more money on education to fix it.

951.16.text: You should say, "Do we, Ted? Do we?"

955.58.text: Because really what we ought to be doing is

962.49.text: not over mandating and over prescribing

965.95.text: where the dollar should be spent.

968.16.text: That we're innovating around new strategies that can help kids learn

973.18.text: and that at the end of the day, we should funnel our resources

976.70.text: to where we know it's working for kids.

979.90.text: That is surely gonna make you the head of the party.
